slidelink.displaytext: What do we mean by knowledge?
The need and value of research knowledge
What makes a worthy research topic?
What makes a worthy research problem?
Research problem - the need to be clear

search.slidetext: developing a research proposal module 1: identifying topics for research

how to navigate to navigate through this module, click on the next button on the bottom right side of the page. alternatively, you can use the index provided on the left hand side. a print version of this module is also available in the resources tab. throughout this module, there are hyperlinks to external websites. in most instances, you will be able to click on the link and a new window will open. however, if this does not work, then the actual url is provided below the link so that you can copy and paste it into a web browser. in addition, all links are provided in a pdf located within the resources tab. all links worked as at 20/2/16. if any links have become broken in the meantime, please let us know. icons are used throughout this module (with the exception of quiz questions), and have the following meanings: resource available useful tip external website

introduction welcome - module 1 comprises the following: a review of module-specific learning outcomes. a preliminary quiz of 3 quick questions on your background experience, which should only take a few minutes. the core content, which has a series of links to websites, examples and journal articles. readings: chapters 1 (p 2-7) and 4 (47-66) of o’leary (2014). overall, this work should take 2 to 6 hours depending on existing knowledge. to finish this module you are required to complete the formative quiz located in the myuni folder for module 1.

learning outcomes let’s begin by reviewing the learning outcomes. by the end of module 1, you should be able to: appreciate the importance, value and construct of research knowledge. identify a range of indicators for research credibility and integrity. list criteria for judging the worthiness of a proposed research topic. understand principles used to derive a problem statement for public health research.

preliminary quiz this quiz consists of three questions. you only need to do this quiz the once. the object is to assess your current understanding of the principles of determining a worthy research topic. there are no right or wrong answers and you will receive feedback on all your answers. proceed to the quiz by clicking next. the next time you access this module, you can proceed directly onto module 1 by clicking either module 1 ,or by using the index on the left hand side.

preliminary quiz question 1 yes yes yes yes yes yes no no no no no no have you had to consider power and privilege issues as a researcher or as a subject in someone else's research? preliminary quiz yes? continue continue continue continue continue continue that's great. can you say a bit more about this on the discussion board for module 1? preliminary quiz no? these are important considerations for credible and ethical research, and will be mentioned in this module. can you think of potential problems that might arise due to the mismatch. (e.g. teachers doing research on students). continue continue continue continue continue continue

preliminary quiz yes yes yes yes yes yes no no no no no no have you previously had to justify a public health research topic in a formal setting (e.g. research group meeting, or for a grant application)? question 2 preliminary quiz yes? continue continue continue continue continue continue terrific! what arguments did you use? please share this insight on the discussion board for module 1. preliminary quiz no? continue continue continue continue continue continue that's ok. there are a number of arguments that you could use, e.g. the prevalence of the condition in the community, costs of treatment etc. you'll the have the opportunity later in the course.

preliminary quiz yes yes yes yes yes yes no no no no no no have you previously written a public health "problem statement" (as distinct from identifying the "research topic")? question 3 preliminary quiz yes? continue continue continue continue continue continue excellent! can you describe how you went about writing the "problem statement" from your topic? was it easy or hard? please share your experience on the discussion board for module 1. preliminary quiz no? continue continue continue continue continue continue this is an important first step in any applied research, and developing this skill will be useful for future research (grants, publications etc.).
preliminary quiz thank you for completing this preliminary quiz. you can now proceed onto module 1.

the "construct" of research module 1 for hundreds of years and until a few decades ago, the construct of research was based on “scientific method”. this was considered positivism, and utilised contrived or natural experiments (human or otherwise), hypotheses, inductive and deductive logic. such was the predictive power of the scientific method and its theories, that it overtook religion and dogma, and was considered to be best method of acquiring new knowledge. even social science was construed in positivism. more recently, research has shifted towards a post-positivist (or postmodern) approach which is more collaborative, participative, idiographic, exploratory and inductive. certainty is replaced by an acceptance of the “unknown”, diversity and multiple realities. this implies socio-historic context, personal experience/interactions etc. (o’leary 2014)

module 2 module 1 what do we mean by knowledge? ontology - relates to the understanding and categorising of what exists. video: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=xtsazwzvj4c epistemology - relates to what is knowledge and the rules for knowing supplementary reading: djulbegovic et al. 2009 epistemologic inquiries in evidence-based medicine knowledge requires justification, truth, and belief. but knowledge is one thing, understanding is another. to be meaningful, research should impart both new knowledge and understanding. redrawn from: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/file:classical_definition_of_kno.svg#mediaviewer/file:classical_definition_of_kno.svg

module 1 the need and value of research knowledge formal research generates new knowledge, which can help us to: understand more about issues and problems. find workable solutions. work towards those solutions. evaluate success. offer robust recommendations. (o’leary 2014) in public health, problems abound. for many public health professionals, public health is about interventions (to reduce inequality, prevent disease and injury, promote health). these interventions should be evidence-based, and can be participatory - in fact it is not the researcher who owns the problem.

module 1 credibility indicators credibility is the quality, capability, or power to elicit belief. credibility can be demonstrated by a range of indicators: whether subjectivities have been acknowledged and managed. whether the ‘true essence’ has been captured. whether the methods were approached with consistency. whether arguments were relevant and appropriate. whether the research can be verified. see table 4.2 of o’leary (2014) for both positivist and post-positivist indicators.

module 1 truth or authenticity? “true essence” where there is uncertainty in classical scientific method, statistical rigour can be applied. e.g. is the sample size sufficient to make inferences about a population with a high degree of confidence? the key notion here is valid truth. (correct for a single reality) in the case of research involving human participants (individually or in communities, workplaces etc), building rapport and trust with participants, and listening to them without judgement is critical in capturing truth. but for multiple realities, it may be authentic truth rather than valid truth.

module 1 integrity, power and privilege research integrity refers to ‘the quality of possessing and steadfastly adhering to high moral principles and professional standards, as outlined by professional organizations, research institutions and, when relevant, the government and public’ (steneck 2006, p 55, citing office of research integrity 2005) steneck n. (2006) fostering integrity in research: definitions, current knowledge, and future directions. science and engineering ethics 12, 53-74. when planning your research you need to consider the power and privilege you may have over your participants or potential participants. this power may be because of your race, age, level of education, or gender. both the integrity of the knowledge produced and the well-being of the research depend on the ethical negotiation of power and power relationships.

module 1 moral obligations some considerations, relating to dignity, welfare, societal norms and values, are: the need to keep the interests of the participants centre stage when making decisions about the conduct of the research. equity. honesty, e,g, in terms of the communication of intent. (o’leary 2014)

module 1 ethical obligations ethics requirements are covered in more detail in module 7. ethical obligations relate to the previously mentioned morals, and may also include: informed consent, from honest and adequate information provision etc. avoidance of harm, which may ultimately impact on what is possible methodologically and legally - for yourself and others. sensitivity to the needs of participants. confidentiality and, if appropriate, anonymity. (o’leary 2014)

module 1 what makes a worthy research topic? you are interested in a topic within public health. the process of finding a research-worthy problem can be imagined as the following flow chart. there are a series of steps, which entail a preliminary scan of the literature and consultation. redrawn from ellis t, levy y. 2008: framework of problem-based research: a guide for novice researchers on the development of a research-worthy problem. informing science: the international journal of an emerging transdiscipline. vol 11, p17 - 33.

module 1 research problem - deconstructing it the research problem is not the same as the research topic. a topic is something to read and obtain information about whereas a problem is something to be solved or framed as a question that must be answered. ellis and levy suggest deconstructing the research problem in terms of “what, why, when, how, where, and who”. kipling’s (1902/1988) “honest serving-men” have been used to form the basis for enquiry in a number of disciplines. although the poem has long been the accepted mantra of journalists, it applies equally well to scientific enquiry. a well-structured, properly-reported study must provide answers to all questions regarding the what, why, when, how, where, and who associated with the research. redrawn from ellis and levy 2008

module 1 research problem - problem statement a worthy topic will have a worthy problem, associated with it. a research-worthy problem statement is the description of an active challenge (i.e. problem) faced by researchers and/or practitioners that does not have adequate solutions available. the problem statement offers the context necessary for addressing the why question.

module 1 what makes a worthy research problem? for public health, indicators of worthiness include: does this problem affect a large number of people (e.g. obesity), or disproportionately affect large subpopulations (workers, children etc.)? does it cost a lot of public money that could be allocated in a different way? (novel cancer treatments, diagnostic technologies). is the problem preventable? often this information is available from disease surveillance statistics (e.g. social health atlas, burden of disease studies etc.). there may be prima facie evidence that a community is being exposed to hazard, e.g. soil contaminant, air pollutant, radiation etc for which there is a clear aetiology of disease, enabling primary prevention.
module 1 research problem - problem statement here is a template suggested by ellis and levy 2008. redrawn from ellis and levy 2008, figure 4.

module 1 research problem - so what? for public health and the social sciences, a worthy research problem also has to pass the “relevancy test”. note that answering the "so what" question requires a commitment on your part to not only show that you have researched the material, but that you have thought about its significance. so what?

module 1 research problem - so what? to survive the "so what" question, problem statements should possess the following attributes: clarity and precision [a well-written statement does not make sweeping generalizations and irresponsible statements], identification of what would be studied, while avoiding the use of value-laden words and terms, identification of an overarching question and key factors or variables, identification of key concepts and terms, articulation of the study's boundaries or parameters, some generalizability in regards to applicability and bringing results into general use, conveyance of the study's importance, benefits, and justification [regardless of the type of research, it is important to address the “so what” question by demonstrating that the research is not trivial], does not have unnecessary jargon; and, conveyance of more than the mere gathering of descriptive data providing only a snapshot of the issue or phenomenon under investigation. the above is taken from a university of southern california website http://libguides.usc.edu/print_content.php?pid=83009&sid=618412
module 1 example problem statements please see the resources tab for example problem statements.
module 1 research problem - the need to be clear first of all, let’s consider the big picture - the research cycle, and where the research problem sits. redrawn from ellis t, levy y. 2008

module 1 research problem once a research-worthy problem is identified, it delimits the formal literature review, which then delimits the purpose statement (and aims), the research question (and hypothesis if applicable) - all described later in the course. the research question (if well formulated) then determines (or creates options for) the methodology*, which produces results, which permits conclusions - hopefully answering the questions. why is it so important for the research process? *the term methodology here incorporates the approach, study design and methods. *described in later modules in the figure, the literature review is seen as supporting and validating the whole cycle.

module 1 conclusion research is a process that leads to new knowledge, a valid truth or an authentic truth. research needs to be (1) worthy, and (2) planned, conducted and communicated with credibility and integrity. a key element of a research proposal is the problem statement. a clearly defined problem helps delimit subsequent stages of the research process. required reading o’leary chapter 1, p 2-7; chapter 4, p 47-66 further optional reading is on the next slide. to finish this module you are required to complete the formative quiz located in the myuni folder for module 1.

module 1 further resources (optional) djulbegovic b, guyatt g, ashcroft r. (2009) epistemologic inquiries in evidence-based medicine. cancer control. 16 (2) 158-68. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19337202 ellis t, levy y. (2008). framework of problem- based research: a guide for novice researchers on the development of a research-worthy problem. informing science: the international journal of an emerging transdiscipline, 11, 17-33. http://www.inform.nu/articles/vol11/isjv11p017-033ellis486.pdf the research problem/question (university of southern california) http://libguides.usc.edu/print_content.php?pid=83009&sid=618412 mccaslin, m. l. & scott, k. w. 2003, ‘the five-question method for framing a qualitative research study’, the qualitative report, vol. 8, no. 3, pp. 447-461. tugwell p, mcgowan j. finding information about the burden of disease. journal of clinical epidemiology 59 (2006) 887e892 social health atlas for australia http://phidu.torrens.edu.au/social-health-atlases
button button button button button button according to the university of adelaide's brand elements
